In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here is the requested Julia code:

```julia
function wrap_string(str, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(str, " ")
    str_out = ""
    for word in words
        if length(word) > text_width || nchar(str_out) + length(word) > text_width
            str_out *= "\n"
        end
        str_out *= word * " "
    end
    return str_out
end

# Test the function:
s = "This is a long string that we will wrap in order to fit within a maximum line width."
println(wrap_string(s))
```

Please note, this function uses the `split` and `length` functions from Julia's standard library. The `length` function returns the length of the string (i.e., number of characters), while `nchar` returns the number of Unicode characters in a string.

The code splits the input string into words and iteratively adds them to a new string (`str_out`). It also checks if adding the current word would exceed the maximum width or if adding the current word to the existing string contents would exceed the maximum width. If either condition is met, it adds a newline character to `str_out`.

Finally, it prints out the wrapped string to the console.
